etymologies: Old English habban, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch hebben and German haben, also probably to heave

notes.text: Have and have got: there is a great deal of debate on the difference between these two forms; a traditional view is that have got is chiefly British, but not correct in formal writing, while have is chiefly American. Actual usage is more complicated: have got is in fact also widely used in US English. In both British and US usage have is more formal than have got and it is more appropriate in writing to use constructions such as don't have rather than haven't got. A common mistake is to write the word of instead of have or 've: I could of told you that instead of I could've told you that. The reason for the mistake is that the pronunciation of have in unstressed contexts is the same as that of of, and the two words are confused when it comes to writing them down. The error was recorded as early as 1837 and, though common, is unacceptable in standard English. Another controversial issue is the insertion of have where it is superfluous, as for example I might have missed it if you hadn't have pointed it out (rather than the standard … if you hadn't pointed it out). This construction has been around since at least the 15th and 16th centuries, but only where a hypothetical situation is presented (e.g. statements starting with if). More recently, there has been speculation among grammarians and linguists that this insertion of have may represent a kind of subjunctive and is actually making a useful distinction in the language. However, it is still regarded as an error in standard English. See also usage at gotten

definitions: possess, own, or hold

examples.text: he had a new car and a boat
have you got a job yet?
I don't have that much money on me
he's got the equipment with him

definitions: possess or be provided with (a quality, characteristic, or feature)

examples.text: the ham had a sweet, smoky flavor
she's got blue eyes
the house has gas heat

definitions: provide or indulge oneself with (something)

examples.text: he had himself two highballs

definitions: be made up of; comprise

examples.text: in 1989 the party had 10,000 members

definitions: used to indicate a particular relationship

examples.text: he's got three children
do you have a client named Pedersen?

definitions: be able to make use of (something available or at one's disposal)

examples.text: how much time have I got for the presentation?

shortDefinitions: be able to make use of

definitions: have gained (a qualification)

examples.text: he's got a BA in English

definitions: possess as an intellectual attainment; know (a language or subject)

examples.text: he knew Latin and Greek; I had only a little French

definitions: experience; undergo

examples.text: I went to a few parties and had a good time
I was having difficulty in keeping awake

definitions: suffer from (an illness, ailment, or disability)

examples.text: I've got a headache

definitions: let (a feeling or thought) come into one's mind; hold in the mind

examples.text: he had the strong impression that someone was watching him
we've got a few ideas we're kicking around
I've no doubt he's as busy as I am

definitions: experience or suffer the specified action happening or being done to (something)

examples.text: she had her bag stolen

shortDefinitions: suffer specified thing being done to

definitions: cause (someone or something) to be in a particular state or condition

examples.text: I want to have everything ready in good time
I had the TV on with the sound turned down

shortDefinitions: cause to be in particular state

definitions: cause (something) to be done for one by someone else

examples.text: it is advisable to have your carpet laid by a professional

shortDefinitions: cause something to be done for one

definitions: tell or arrange for something to be done

examples.text: always having the builders in to do something
she had her long hair cut

shortDefinitions: arrange for someone to do something

definitions: have put (someone) at a disadvantage in an argument (said either to acknowledge that one has no answer to a point or to show that one knows one's opponent has no answer)

examples.text: you've got me there; I've never given the matter much thought

shortDefinitions: have someone at disadvantage in argument

definitions: cheat or deceive (someone)

examples.text: I realized I'd been had

definitions: have sex with.
be obliged or find it necessary to do the specified thing

examples.text: you don't have to accept this situation
we've got to plan for the future

notes.text: "have to do something" or "have got to do something"

definitions: need or be obliged to do (something)

examples.text: he's got a lot to do

shortDefinitions: need or be obliged to do

definitions: be strongly recommended to do something

examples.text: if you think that place is great, you have to try our summer house

definitions: be certain or inevitable to happen or be the case

examples.text: there has to be a catch

definitions: perform the action indicated by the noun specified (used especially in spoken English as an alternative to a more specific verb)

examples.text: he had a look around
the color green has a restful effect

definitions: organize and bring about

examples.text: are you going to have a party?

definitions: eat or drink

examples.text: I'll have the vegetable plate

definitions: give birth to or be due to give birth to

examples.text: she's going to have a baby

definitions: show (a personal attribute or quality) by one's actions or attitude

examples.text: he had little patience with technological gadgetry
if you've got the drive to finish your degree

definitions: exercise or show (mercy, pity, etc.) toward another person

examples.text: God have mercy on me!

shortDefinitions: exercise mercy, pity, etc. towards another

definitions: not accept; refuse to tolerate

examples.text: I can't have you insulting Tom like that

definitions: place or keep (something) in a particular position

examples.text: Mary had her back to me
I soon had the trout in a net

shortDefinitions: place or keep in particular position

definitions: hold or grasp (someone or something) in a particular way

examples.text: he had me by the throat

shortDefinitions: hold or grasp in particular way

definitions: be the recipient of (something sent, given, or done)

examples.text: she had a letter from Mark

definitions: take or invite into one's home so as to provide care or entertainment, especially for a limited period

examples.text: we're having the children for the weekend

notes.text: Have and have got: there is a great deal of debate on the difference between these two forms; a traditional view is that have got is chiefly British, but not correct in formal writing, while have is chiefly American. Actual usage is more complicated: have got is in fact also widely used in US English. In both British and US usage have is more formal than have got and it is more appropriate in writing to use constructions such as don't have rather than haven't got. A common mistake is to write the word of instead of have or 've: I could of told you that instead of I could've told you that. The reason for the mistake is that the pronunciation of have in unstressed contexts is the same as that of of, and the two words are confused when it comes to writing them down. The error was recorded as early as 1837 and, though common, is unacceptable in standard English. Another controversial issue is the insertion of have where it is superfluous, as for example I might have missed it if you hadn't have pointed it out (rather than the standard … if you hadn't pointed it out). More recently, there has been speculation among grammarians and linguists that this insertion of have may represent a kind of subjunctive and is actually making a useful distinction in the language. However, it is still regarded as an error in standard English. See also usage at gotten

definitions: used with a past participle to form the perfect, pluperfect, and future perfect tenses, and the conditional mood

examples.text: I have finished
he had asked her
she will have left by now
I could have helped, had I known
“Have you seen him?” “Yes, I have.”

shortDefinitions: used with past participle to form tenses

definitions: people with plenty of money and possessions

examples.text: an increasing gap between the haves and have-nots
